questions.stem: A 26-year-old woman complains of a mass in her vagina. The mass is non-tender, but is uncomfortable during exertion. It appears on standing and disappears on lying down, and can be reduced manually. Most likely diagnosis:
A 28-year-old G1P1 woman complains of severe painful regular menses and severe dyspareunia. She has no history of STDs or PID. Most likely to identify the cause is:

On a laparoscopy on a 28-year-old patient, multiple implants of endometriosis on the uterosacral ligaments and ovaries were detected. you ablated all the visible lesions with CO2 laser. You recommended postoperative medical treatment due to extensive lesions seen intra-operatively. The best method used to follow up the prognosis:
A 28-year-old NG complains of bleeding between periods and heavy menses. She tried OCPs and NSAIDs with no effect. The most appropriate at this time:
options: Start the patient on a high dose progestational agent.

questions.stem: A copper IUD has a contraception efficacy rate of:
Which of the following is true regarding the use of a contraceptive diaphragm:
options: It must be refitted if the patient gains more than 7kg.
Use of nonoxynol-9 will prevent HIV.
The diaphragm should be removed immediately after intercourse.
Diaphragms are made only of latex.
Diaphragms are recommended for women with a history of toxic shock syndrome.

questions.stem: A 37-year-old woman who complains of heavy painful menses requests contraception. She smokes a pack of cigarettes a day. Best choice of contraception for this patient:

A 36-year-old woman has severe pain during menses which radiates into the anal region. On bimanual exam, she has a small, retroverted uterus and tender nodules can be felt on palpation of the uterosacral ligaments. which of the following does she most likely have?

A 32-year-old G5P4 presents with an 8week history of amenorrhea and suggestive symptoms of pregnancy. Physical examination reveals enlarged uterus 16weeks. US confirms the presence of an 8weeks living pregnancy and a multiple fibroid uterus. The correct management for this patient is:
options: Termination of pregnancy with elective myomectomy 2months later.
Termination of pregnancy with concomitant myomectomy.
Prudent observation with elective C-section at term.
Prudent observation anticipating probable vaginal delivery.
Myomectomy and follow pregnancy in usual way.

questions.stem: The commonest type of bleeding encountered with uterine leiomyomas is:
A 36-year-old G1P1 presents wz pain& bleeding due to a large uterine fibroid confirmed by US. Patient requests treatment but wants to preserve fertility. Best treatment is:

A 37-year-old P2 presents with a 10day history of heavy vaginal bleeding and lower abdominal cramping. O/E: 6cm submucosal myoma seen from the cervix. Active bleeding is present, and the patient's hematocrit is 26%. The following is optimal management:
options: Biopsy of the mass and transfusion is necessary.
Transvaginal myomectomy and transfusion if necessary.

questions.stem: A 72-year-old woman complains of a lump protruding through the vagina with local pressure symptoms. O/E, there is a visible uterine prolapse. All the following may be etiologic factors EXCEPT:
Oral contraceptive pills have been shown to raise the risk of:
Which of the following is also associated with combined oral contraceptive use:

A 19-year-old female comes to see you because she found a tear in her diaphragm contraceptive device. She had intercourse the previous day. She is worried about unwanted pregnancy. What is the appropriate action?
options: Levonorgestrel, one pill now and another in 12hrs.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old P4 on continuous combined HRT, presents with a 2weeks history of irregular vaginal bleeding. best next step:
What is the commonest cause of postmenopausal bleeding:
A 40-year-old woman complains of menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea that progressed gradually; the most likely diagnosis is:
A 33-year-old female presents with 3months irregular vaginal bleeding. prior, her menstrual periods were normal. The most appropriate initial laboratory test is:
The most frequent cause of dyspareunia is:

A 26-year-old woman is first seen at 28weeks gestation. Her history and physical examination are normal except for the presence of a 2cm posterior cervical leiomyoma. Best management for this patient:
options: Progesterone therapy to decrease the myoma size.
Cesarean section and myomectomy at the same setting.

questions.stem: A 32-year-old woman complains of heavy menstrual bleeding for 8months. O/E: no physical abnormality. She feels very fatigued. which investigation you would consider first:

A 57-year-old postmenopausal woman complains of "something coming out of her vagina" and difficulty in opening her bowels. she had 4 children by normal vaginal deliveries. her last child birth was 18yrs ago. The most likely diagnosis:
Regarding endometriosis, all the following are correct EXCEPT:

A 36-year-old woman is diagnosed with mild stage pelvic endometriosis at laparoscopy. she has regular cycles; her partner has normal semen analysis. The couple have been trying to conceive for 2years. The preferred initial ttt choice:
options: Laparoscopic excision/ ablation of peritoneal endometriosis.

questions.stem: A 22-year-old woman asks her GP for most appropriate postnatal contraception for her. she had uncomplicated VD 6weeks ago. She is intermittently breast feeding. She and her partner are keen to space out 2-3yrs and requesting the most reliable contraception. She admits having difficulty in remembering to take medication. Most appropriate option:

A 22-year-old woman presents to her GP for advice regarding postnatal contraception. She had an uncomplicated VD 3weeks ago. She is bottle feeding. She and her partner are keen to space out 1-2years and wishing a reliable form of contraception. She has history of irregular menstrual cycles and PCO. Most appropriate option:

A 38-year-old woman suffers from 1ry infertility and endometriosis. Her recent TVS suggests presence of 2.5cm endometrioma. Her pain is well controlled using simple analgesics. she is due to undergo IVF. Best ttt for this endometrioma
options: Laparoscopic ovarian cyst fenestration and drainage.

questions.stem: Medical management of fibroids is best indicated when:
options: Fibroid less than 3cm, not distorting the cavity and asymptomatic.
Fibroid less than 3cm, distorting the cavity and asymptomatic.
Fibroid less than 3cm, not distorting the cavity and causing heavy bleeding.
Fibroid more than 3cm, distorting the cavity and asymptomatic.
Fibroid more than 3cm, not distorting the cavity and asymptomatic.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old patient presents to ER 2days after UAE (Uterine Artery Embolization) for a 20weeks size fibroid uterus. She has diffused abdominal pain, generalized malaise, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, low-grade fever and leukocytosis. Most likely diagnosis:

A 17-year-old girl complains of severe bleeding during her menstrual cycle. She uses 20 tampons per cycle, and it lasts for 7days. She denies being sexually active. What is the first line of medical therapy for this patient:

A 28-year-old white female consults you for irregular heavy menstrual periods. her general and pelvic examination as Pap test examination as well as TVS are normal. She has a negative pregnancy test. CBC and chemistry are normal. the next step should be:

A 36-year-old woman attends the family planning clinic as she wants to use COCP for the next 3years and she is asking about the risks of thromboembolism. When does she have the highest risk of venous thromboembolism?
options: In the second year of use.
In the first year of use.

questions.stem: The most common cause of stress incontinence is:
O/E of a 35-year-old multipara complaining of lower abdominal heaviness, uterus was felt symmetrically enlarged of about 12 weeks size. All the following could be an etiology EXCEPT:
A 35-year-old NG complains of increasing dysmenorrhea and pelvic pain. She has not become pregnant over her 3years. PV shows tenderness of a 4cm right ovarian cyst. Most likely diagnosis:
The most common early complication of Burch colposuspension is:
A young female enters your office wanting to start oral contraceptive pills. You counsel her the reasons she may not start pills, which are:
A 55-year-old female presents with a period like vaginal bleeding for 5days that stopped spontaneously. Your approach to the problem would be:
options: Reassure the patient and manage expectantly.
Perform Pap smear plus endocervical curettage.

questions.stem: Prolapse after menopause is attributed to the deficiency of which hormone:

A 25-year-old P1+0, is seeking a method of contraception. She delivered by CS 3months ago and is nursing her baby with amenorrhea since delivery. She is planning to delay next pregnancy for 3-5years. Most appropriate contraceptive method for her is:
options: Lactation suppresses ovulation and no extra protection.

questions.stem: A 38-year-old P1+0 attends the outpatient clinic for a contraceptive advice 2 months after CS. She is nursing her baby with amenorrhea and has not decided yet for how long she will delay the next pregnancy. Most appropriate contraceptive method:
options: No need as long as lactational amenorrhea is present.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old multipara, menopausal for 10 years, presents with slight vaginal bleeding. She is hypertensive with poor control. Speculum examination is free and US reveals normal size AVF uterus with 10mm endometrial thickness. Best management is:
options: Check FSH and E2 before taking an action.
Gestagens could be used for 6 months.
Pelvic MRI for further uterine evaluation.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old multipara, menopausal for 10 years, presents by an attack of mild vaginal bleeding. She is known to be hypertensive with poor control. Ultrasound reveals AVF normal sized uterus with a 2 mm endometrial thickness. How will you proceed?
options: Check FSH and LH levels before taking an action.

questions.stem: The following is an absolute contraindication to combined oral contraceptive pills:
Indications to interfere in a uterine myoma include one of the following:
options: Submucous fibroid polyp in infertile case.

questions.stem: Woman with endometriosis is likely to complain of all the following EXCEPT:
Regarding malignant transformation of uterine fibroid, choose the correct statement:
options: Commonly presents with acute abdominal pain.
Post-menopausal growth in absence of replacement therapy is characteristic.
It is more common in cervical fibroids.

questions.stem: A 48-year-old multipara with regular cycles, presents with repeated attacks of contact bleeding. Causes may include all the following EXCEPT:
In the previous patient, which of the following investigations will be most valuable?
A 50-year-old P1+2 presented with heavy menstrual flow for one year. TVS revealed a submucous fibroid 4cm filling the uterine cavity. Best treatment is:
A 30-year-old P1+2 presents with heavy menstrual flow for one year. US reveals a submucous fibroid filling the uterine cavity. Best treatment option is:

A 37-year-old multiparous woman presents with sexual unsatisfaction and mass protruding through the vulva on straining. O/E, the mass is soft, pinkish, mainly from the lower part of posterior vaginal wall. Most probable cause is:

A 30-year-old primipara presents 2 months after vaginal delivery with lack of sexual satisfaction. Examination reveals a weak levator ani tone with intact perineum. Cervix is felt just above the level of ischial spines. What is the suitable treatment option?
What is the most common presentation of myoma:
Indications to interfere in asymptomatic myoma include one of the following:
A 30-year-old P1+2, presented by heavy menstrual flow for lyear. TVS revealed a submucous fibroid 4cm filling the uterine cavity. Best treatment option to preserve fertility:
Common symptoms associating endometriosis are:

a 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for advice regarding birth control. She has tried OCPs twice, for approximately two cycles each time, but stopped because of irregular bleeding. She has had gonorrhea once. Examination is unremarkable. Which of the following forms of birth control should be recommended for her:
What is the advice you should give to the woman:
options: You have to do laparoscopy to check the condition of Fallopian tubes.
You should bring your husband for examination for gonorrhea.
You have to drain your Bartholin gland.
You have to receive treatment on regular basis to prevent reinfection.

questions.stem: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bleeding from the vagina. She has no medical problems and takes no medications. Endometrial biopsy is performed. The patient complains of discomfort after the procedure but feels well enough to go home. Later that night, her abdominal pain worsened. She comes to ER. US shows a normal uterus and adnexae but a complex fluid collection posterior to the uterus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
What is the most suitable management:

A 54-year-old woman complains of hot flushes and cold sweats. Her LMP was 3years ago. She is on HRT. She noticed vaginal bleeding 2weeks ago. The bleeding is bright red painless following intercourse. Patient is concerned about tumor risk. What is the following next step in the management of this case:
options: Perform speculum examination and obtain Pap smear

questions.stem: TVS revealed endometrial thickness of 8mm. Next step in the management of this case:
options: Decrease the dose of estrogen replacement therapy.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old NG recently married (since 1year) presented because of her infertility problem. Her menstrual period is irregular and heavy since 6months and lasts for 8days with cramps and pain in her lower abdomen. She has been diagnosed to have hypochromic microcytic anemia and she is on iron supplement. Her hormonal analysis revealed normal FSH, LH, TSH and PRL level. Her BBT chart is biphasic. her HSG that revealed patent tubes but the uterine cavity showed a 2cm filling defect. What is the most likely diagnosis:
What is the most appropriate next step:

A 38-year-old woman G4P4 with all NVD comes to the physician with involuntary escape of urine. She also noticed a swelling that comes out of her vagina on straining. She pushes this swelling inside her vagina and rest in bed as treatment. This mass disappears on lying down but the escape of urine on coughing did not improve. What is the most likely diagnosis:
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management:
Choose the correct statement as regard treatment of endometriosis:
options: Cyclic OCP could be used for 6monbths.
Danazole is the treatment of choice for 1-2years.
Long acting GnRh agonists could be used for 6months.
Small dose estrogen can be used to reduce the associated pain.
Surgical excision should be offered in all patients.

questions.stem: A 40-year-old P2+0 diabetic attended the clinic for contraception. She had regular cycles but she used to have more than average blood loss for about 7days. Examination and TVS were normal. Most appropriate method for contraception for her:

A 50-year patient had undergone a vaginal hysterectomy 3 months ago for a complete uterine prolapse. Since the operation she complains of involuntary continuous urine leakage although she feels normal desire of micturition. Provisional cause for this incontinence:
Regarding parameters of normal bladder functions on cystometry:
options: Presence of detrusor contractions during filling.
First desire to void at 400 ml.

questions.stem: The commonest cause of rectovaginal fistula is:

A 45-year-old multiparous woman had 2ry dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia for 2 years. Examination revealed mild symmetric enlarged uterus with mild tenderness. Pelvic ultrasound revealed diffuse thickening of uterine muscles. Most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is considered a contraindication to IUCD?
The most common risk factor for pelvic organ prolapse is:
options: Iatrogenic weakness following improperly formed hysterectomy.

questions.stem: A 45-year multipara, presented with a mass protruding from the vulva on straining. This was associated with some urinary frequency and lack of sexual satisfaction. Examination revealed a descent of both anterior and posterior vaginal wall with deficient perineum. Cervix was felt at level of ischial spines. Most suitable treatment for her?
An enterocele is best characterized by which of the following statements:
options: It is not a true hernia.
It is a herniation of the bladder floor into the vagina.
It is a prolapse of the uterus and vaginal wall outside the body.
It is protrusion of the pelvic peritoneal sac and vaginal wall into the vagina.
It is a prolapse of the vaginal wall with the lower rectum.

questions.stem: All the followings are true about IUCD EXCEPT:
options: It is contraindicated in undiagnosed vaginal bleeding.
It is contraindicated in cases with history of PID.
It is contraindicated in patients with a history of ectopic pregnancy.
It is contraindicated in patients with uterine anomalies making insertion difficult.
It is contraindicated in lactating patients.

questions.stem: All the following are side effects of COCPS EXCEPT:
Choose one of the following conditions in which COCPs could be safely prescribed?
The absolute contraindications to COCPs include all the following EXCEPT:
All the following are considered a temporary method of contraception EXCEPT:
The commonest contraceptive method used in developing countries is:
COCPs increase the risk of all the following EXCEPT:
A 26-year-old newly married female comes with her husband due to severe dyspareunia and failed intercourse. All the following can contribute to this condition EXCEPT:
Menorrhagia could be caused by all the following EXCEPT:
options: Corpus luteum cyst of the ovary.

questions.stem: For injectable progesterone contraception, all the following are true EXCEPT:
options: Medroxyprogesterone acetate is the most commonly used.
Should not be given in lactating mother.
Does not carry a risk of venous thrombosis.

questions.stem: Side effects of OCP include all the following EXCEPT:
A contraceptive method that prevents transmission of STD is:
All the following are possible causes of menorrhagia EXCEPT:
All the following are suggestive of adenomyosis, EXCEPT:
options: Boggy globular and tender uterus with indistinct endometrial-myometrial junction.
Enlarged firm uterus with distinct masses on ultrasound.

questions.stem: A 68-year-old patient presents with pelvic pressure, vaginal bulge that worsens by prolonged standing. You suspect POP. All the following contribute to POP EXCEPT:
options: Chronic constipation with a long-standing straining to defecate.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old obese asymptomatic G5P4 was referred for evaluation of mild POP. She denies any pelvic pressure, bulge or difficult urination. What do u recommend:
options: Conservative management with pelvic floor muscle exercise and weight loss.

questions.stem: The treatment of endometriosis include all the following EXCEPT:
Clinical symptoms of uterine prolapse include all the following, EXCEPT:
The following are theories for endometriosis EXCEPT:
The commonest uterine fibroid to cause excessive bleeding is:
Acceptable treatment for uterine fibroids include all the following EXCEPT:
options: Myomectomy during pregnancy if red degeneration occurs.

questions.stem: Regarding uterine fibroid:
options: Is commoner in white people than black races.
In pregnancy, this indicates cesarean section.

questions.stem: A patient has uterine leiomyoma accompanied by excessive uterine bleeding, TVS showed thick endometrium of 13mm. Your management should be by:

A 30-year-old P2+0, inserted an IUD 1 month after her last repeat cesarean section. During IUD checkup 6 months later, the threads were not felt or seen on speculum examination. TVS revealed an empty normal sized uterus with free adnexae. What will your next investigation be?
If this IUD is present outside the uterus, what is the most suitable management?

A 24-year-old G2P2 is requesting contraception 6weeks postpartum. Her history is unremarkable except for significant 1ry dysmenorrhea. The following contraceptive methods may increase the dysmenorrhea:

A 90-year-old woman comes to your office complaining that she feels she is "sitting on a ball". O/E, you find that the vagina turned inside out and the entire uterus lies outside the vaginal introitus. This condition is known as:
A 25-year-old woman requests emergency contraception after unprotected intercourse on an occasion 4days ago. What would you recommend:
A 32-year-old woman underwent TVS for Rt sided pelvic pain. US shows Rt ovarian cyst 5x4x6cm with ground glass appearance. Most likely diagnosis:

A 32-year-old NG comes for consultation as she and her husband are planning conception. TVS: 7cm uterus with 1x2cm intramural fibroid, no adenomyosis, endometrial lining and ovaries are normal. She has mild dysmenorrhea, no AUB, no postcoital or intermenstrual bleeding. Her examination is unremarkable. Your recommended treatment:

A 62-year-old G2P2 presents with urinary incontinence. She can't make it to the toilet. She gets up 2-3times per night to urinate. Urine analysis, culture were negative. Most likely diagnosis and most appropriate treatment:
Which of the following factors predispose to genital prolapse:
A 35-year-old woman has been placed on POP for 5 years. All the following are mechanism of action of POP EXCEPT:
options: Making the endometrium unsuitable for implantation.

questions.stem: Operative laparoscopy is the best therapeutic approach for:
A 35-year-old multipara discovered accidently that she has an intramural myoma 3cm. Proper management is:
options: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
Total abdominal hysterectomy with ovarian preservation.

questions.stem: Combined oral contraceptive pills may be associated with:
All the following are causes of vaginal prolapse EXCEPT:
Select the correct statement regarding cystocele:
options: Is a descent of the posterior vaginal wall.
Is mainly due to defective pelvic innervation.
Should be associated with uterine descent.
Can be differentiated from rectocele by ultrasound examination.

questions.stem: A 35 years old multipara has descent of anterior and posterior vaginal walls with cervix felt at level of ischial spines and showing elongation. She is best treated by:
Main presenting symptom/sign for adenomyosis:
Regarding intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD):
options: Some types are medicated with estrogen.
Upward migration may occur at any time after insertion.
Mainly act through inducing inflammatory uterine reaction.

questions.stem: A 6 weeks pregnant woman presents with invisible IUD threads. Ultrasonography confirms a pulsating intra uterine pregnancy. The appropriate management is:
options: Antibiotics for the rest of pregnancy.

questions.stem: The benefit of levonorgestrel- IUS over copper IUD is:
options: Less risk of occurrence of ectopic pregnancy.

questions.stem: The following contraceptive method is better avoided during lactation:
A 24-year-old lady complains of menorrhagia of 6 months duration. Her examination and ultrasound are normal. First line of treatment will be:
Non contraceptive benefits of COCPs include all the following EXCEPT:
options: Can be used to delay menstruation.
Less risk of non-neoplastic ovarian functional cysts.

questions.stem: Contraceptive method which is not be used by a patient with coronary heart disease:
A 20-year-old NG presents with complete extrusion of the uterus. Best treatment:

A 50-year patient had undergone a vaginal hysterectomy 3months ago for a complete uterine prolapse. Since the operation she complains of continuous urine leakage and does not feel bladder filling. Cause for this incontinence:
What is the most common presentation of interstitial cervical fibroid?
Choose the correct statement regarding treatment of endometriosis:
options: Continuous OCP could be used for 6 months to induce pseudo-pregnancy.
Danazol is the treatment of choice for 1 to 2 years.
Gn RH agonists can cause disease progression.
Expectant management is indicated in cases with large endometrioma.
Surgical excision should be offered in all cases.

questions.stem: A 60 years old woman complains of urine loss with coughing and sneezing, a diagnosis of stress urinary incontinence is made. The first line of treatment is:
A 35-year-old female complains of menorrhagia for one-year, bimanual examination shows asymmetrical uterus 16 weeks size. The most probable diagnosis:

A 30 years old woman pregnant in her 10th weeks is complaining of severe pelvic pain and sudden abdominal enlargement. Ultrasound done a month ago, showed normal intrauterine pregnancy and a 5cm interstitial fundal myoma. Most probable diagnosis is:
options: Impaction of the myoma in the pelvic cavity.
Coincidental pain not related to myoma.

questions.stem: A 40-year-old G3P3 complains of involuntary dribbling when she coughs or sneezes 6 months after her last vaginal delivery. She has no dysuria or frequency. The first investigation needed for this patient is:
Based on her history and presentation, the most likely diagnosis is:
As next step in management, your recommendation to the patient is:
options: Instruct her to start performing Kegel exercise.
Tell her to hold her urine for 6 hours to enlarge her bladder capacity.
Instruct her to moderate her daily fluid intake.

questions.stem: This patient returns to your office 6 months later, with recurrence of the same symptoms, after partial improvement. Best next step in management:
If this patient developed later inability to hold urine and start leaking before reaching WC. Your management would be:
Regarding red degeneration in fibroids, all are true EXCEPT:
options: Surgery is the first line of treatment.
Can occur in postmenopausal women on HRT.

questions.stem: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with anovulatory DUB. Best medical therapy:
options: Oral estrogen for the first 25days of the cycle.
Oral progesterone 5-10mg daily for 10days each month.

questions.stem: A 42-year-old P5 complains of heavy menstrual bleeding and anemia. US shows multiple fibroids around 3cm. She has some pressure symptoms. First ttt option:
The benefit of UAE in treatment of fibroid uterus is:

A 24-year-old NG complains of worsening dysmenorrhea for the last 6months after stopping her OCPs. She also complains of deep dyspareunia. You suspect that she may also have endometriosis. You should counsel her about the potential results of endometriosis as:

A 17-year-old consults you for evaluation of disabling pain with her menstrual periods. The pain has been present since menarche, and is accompanied by nausea and headache. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and pelvic examination is normal. She is not currently sexually active, and she has not tried any therapy for her dysmenorrhea.

A 19-year-old college student is seen for severe primary dysmenorrhea. She has no medical problems and a normal pelvic examination. She has recently become sexually active and doesn't currently desire pregnancy.

A 24-year-old lady just delivered, without complications, 2 months ago. She is bottle feeding and seeking contraception. She gives history of irregular menses. Her medical, surgical and family histories are irrelevant.
A 43-year-old lady, with heavy menstrual bleeding, is seeking contraception. Her medical, surgical and family histories are irrelevant. She is not compliant for regular forms of contraception.
A 35-year-old lady, just delivered her first baby 6 weeks ago, is requesting contraception for short term duration. She is breast feeding, with irrelevant medical, surgical and family histories.
A 40-year-old hypertensive multiparous lady is requesting contraception. She has regular menses with irrelevant surgical and family histories.
A 30-year-old woman with history of prolonged menstruation developed DVT on COCPs. She came asking about another method of contraception to be used for just one-year duration.
A 49-year-old woman complains that "her organs are progressively falling out of her vagina", with losing urine on coughing, and feeling incomplete emptying of her bladder with voiding.
A 56-year-old woman complains that she is "sitting on a ball". She says constipation is a significant problem. Sometimes she needs to press in her vagina to allow stool to come out of the rectum.

A 68-year-old woman complains of something falling out of her vagina. She feels constant backache. 4yrs ago, she had abdominal hysterectomy & Burch operation. Her ability to hold urine is excellent now.
Laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosis and treatment of uterine adenomyosis.
Important causes of dyspareunia include endometriosis and chronic salpingitis.
The risk of postoperative thrombo-embolism increases with age, obesity, prolonged bed rest and use of combined oral contraceptive pills.
Drugs used in treatment of detrusor over activity are para-sympathomimetics.
One of the non-contraceptive uses of COPs is the delay menses.
The first investigation needed to screen a postmenopausal bleeding case is hysteroscopy.
Most common side effect of copper IUD is heavy menstrual flow.
